Problem:
Consider the scenario where a complex function \\( z(t) \\) evolves in the complex plane under the differential equation \\( \\dot{z} = i\\omega z \\) where \\( \\omega \\) is a real constant. We study how the Fourier Transform, defined by \\( \\mathcal{F}(z(t)) = \\int_{-\\infty}^{\\infty} z(t)e^{-i\\omega t} dt \\), affects our understanding of the system.

If an intervention alters \\( z(t) \\) by applying a phase shift \\( z(t) \\rightarrow z(t)e^{i\\theta} \\) at some time \\( t_1 \\), will the endpoint of the Fourier Transform of \\( z(T) \\) for \\( T > t_1 \\) depend solely on \\( \\omega \\) and not on \\( \\theta \\)?
Explanation: The intervention introduces a phase shift which affects the Fourier Transform output by adding a complex phase factor. The final state of the Fourier Transform will definitely depend on the value of \\( \\theta \\) as well as \\( \\omega \\), altering the amplitude and phase of the resulting frequency components.
causal_map_prompt: You are an expert in causal reasoning. Given the following problem description and question, identify all relevant variables and describe their direct causal relationships.Your output should be a clear causal map in textual form, listing directed causal links as "A → B" (meaning A directly causes B).Avoid redundancy or duplicate links. List only distinct and meaningful causal relations. Do not provide any final answer to the question. Focus only on extracting the causal structure. Output strictly in JSON format: {"causal_relation": "A → B; C → D; ..."}.
causal_map: ω → z(t); z(t) → z(t)e^(iθ); z(t)e^(iθ) → z(T); z(T) → ℱ(z(T)); ℱ(z(T)) → endpoint of ℱ(z(T))
